0.title: Bump lodash from 4.17.5 to 4.17.14
0.body:
Bumps [lodash](https://github.com/lodash/lodash) from 4.17.5 to 4.17.14.
Commits - [`be87d30`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/be87d303941222b97c482755afc0f4a77ce46c30) Bump to v4.17.14. - [`a6fe6b1`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/a6fe6b1e174fd02b5e60eb2664405f4c1262c300) Rebuild lodash and docs. - [`e371828`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/e37182845f16715a0d1c391c8662d83c55609cee) Bump to v4.17.13. - [`357e899`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/357e899e685872b4af5403ecc4b2a928f961ae63) Rebuild lodash and docs. - [`fd9a062`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/fd9a062d57646450b61f74029315abd4cc834b08) Bump to v4.17.12. - [`e77d681`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/e77d68121ff00ba86b53eed5893d35adfe94c9dd) Rebuild lodash and docs. - [`629d186`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/629d1865793182cd967196716f4beff223aa4a91) Update OpenJS references. - [`2406eac`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/2406eac542b2a1282be8d812a6d8a45433ade80a) Fix minified build. - [`17a34bc`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/17a34bc5854bb982ef333bfe7ae469f4dfcee0ec) Fix test bootstrap for core build. - [`53838a3`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/53838a38f8e4f6204ef2f837fecc4e07d09afe77) Fix tests in older browsers. - Additional commits viewable in [compare view](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/compare/4.17.5...4.17.14)

2.title: [enhance] Allow schemas to have extraneous attributes that are simply ignored
2.body:
<!--
Thank you so much for contributing to open source and the Normalizr project!
-->
# Problem

Sometimes it might be useful to express more in a schema object to be used by other utilities. For instance, having default values for other attributes that are expected in a response but don't turn into entities.

# Solution

Pretty simple: in unvisit we check if schema is really a schema, otherwise we just return input.

Note: this extends off https://github.com/paularmstrong/normalizr/pull/365 as I am building on the type changes there.

# TODO

- [x] Add & update tests
- [x] Ensure CI is passing (lint, tests, flow)
- [ ] Update relevant documentation

If you donâ€™t accept this pull request, your project will work just like it did before. However, you might be missing out on a bunch of new features, fixes and/or performance improvements from the dependency update. ---
Release Notes for v9.0.0

9.0.0 (2019-07-01)

Bug Fixes

  • parse titles for function linters (e24aaf2)

Code Refactoring

  • remove advanced configuration options (04190c8)
  • remove support for chunking (2ca9050)
  • use execa's shell option to run commands (bed9127)

Features

  • add --shell and --quiet flags (ecf9227)
  • add deprecation error for advanced configuration (4bef26e)
  • support function linter returning array of commands (36e54a2)
  • support functions as linter commands (f76c0d1)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • The advanced configuration options have been deprecated in favour of the simple format
  • Local commands are no longer resolved by lint-staged, but execa will do this instead. In effect, there are no longer pretty error messages when commands are not found.
  • Very long arguments strings are no longer chunked on Windows. Function linters should be used instead to customise this behaviour.
Commits

The new version differs by 32 commits.

  • e24aaf2 fix: parse titles for function linters
  • e862e7e docs: correct config file name
  • 309ff1c docs: restore filtering section to README
  • 4bef26e feat: add deprecation error for advanced configuration
  • e829646 refactor: remove dependency on path-is-inside
  • 767edbd refactor: remove dependency on lodash
  • c59cd9a chore: upgrade dependencies
  • 19536e3 refactor: pass unparsed commands to execa with --shell
  • 275d996 refactor: rename --silent to --quiet
  • 18acd59 docs: update README
  • 2ba6d61 test: ignore testSetup from coverage report
  • ecf9227 feat: add --shell and --quiet flags
  • 04190c8 refactor: remove advanced configuration options
  • bed9127 refactor: use execa's shell option to run commands
  • d3f6475 docs: update contributors

There are 32 commits in total.

5.title: Incorrect denormalization of partially normalized entities
5.body:
# Problem

If some non-normalized data, but described in schema, is stored in my normalized entity , then this data will be broken when entity is denormalized.
The problem appeared in version 3.2.4. In version 3.2.3 it was not there yet.

**Example:**
https://codesandbox.io/s/normalizr-test-case-hyn4d

**Working example in v3.2.3:**
https://codesandbox.io/s/normalizr-test-case-y3fp0

12.title: fix(schemas): don't use schema to attribute mapping on singular array schemas
12.body:
<!--
Thank you so much for contributing to open source and the Normalizr project!
-->
# Problem

Denormalization does not seem to produce the correct result when a singular Array schema owns an Object schema whose instances own an `id` property. 

For example:

```javascript
const cats = new schema.Entity('cats');
// catRecord instances own an `id` property
const catRecord = new schema.Object({
   cat: cats
});
const catList = new schema.Array(catRecord);
```

The problem is in the the `denormalizeValue` method of the `Polymorphic` class.

When the value to be unvisited owns a property named `id`, then this method uses the value of the `id` property as the input value for the call to `unvisit` in place of the value itself, which is not the case on singular Array schema, where the value itself should always be used instead.

# Solution

I've added a guard which prevents the value of the `id` property to become the input to `unvisit` when the current schema is a singular schema.

# TODO

- [ x] Add & update tests
- [ x] Ensure CI is passing (lint, tests, flow)
- [ ] Update relevant documentation

13.title: Performance problem in v3.4.0 [needs repro]
13.body:
# Problem with normalizr performance

After updating 'normalizr' from 3.3.0 to 3.4.0, my project has dropped significantly in performance.

14.title: Fix schema key is not in entities
14.body:
<!--
Thank you so much for contributing to open source and the Normalizr project!
-->
# Problem

Currently, `denormalize` sets value to `undefined` If did not find entity.

Example:
```javascript
const entities = {
  comments: { '1': { user: '123' } },
  users: {}  // 123 is not found
};
console.log(denormalize('1', comment, entities));  // { user: undefined }
```


But, If entities don't have "schema key", `denormalize` throw exception.

Example:
```javascript
const entities = {
  comments: { '1': { user: '123' } },
  // user: {}
};
console.log(denormalize('1', comment, entities));  // TypeError: Cannot read property '123' of undefined
```

I think the correct behavior is to set undefined if the entities have no schema key.

# Solution
Add `entities[schemaKey]` check to `getEntities` method.

# TODO

- [x] Add & update tests
- [x] Ensure CI is passing (lint, tests, flow)
- [x] Update relevant documentation

15.title: [minor] Improve typescript types with generics
15.body:
<!--
Thank you so much for contributing to open source and the Normalizr project!
-->
# Problem
It's very hard to infer anything about the types without generics. Given that it's most useful to have types for the data stored in your normalized cache this seems pretty essential.

# Solution
The idea here is at some point you'll point to an entity whose processStrategy will return the type you expect.

Splitting the Schema union type was essential to distinguish between list results and singular results as well.

In the end I was able to create my own type in userland that could extract what type to expect:
```typescript
export type SchemaOf<T> = T extends SchemaArray<infer R>
  ? R[]
  : T extends SchemaBase<infer R>
    ? R
    : never;
```

# TODO

- [x] Add & update tests
- [x] Ensure CI is passing (lint, tests, flow)
- [x] Update relevant documentation

16.title: Normalize reverse collection
16.body:
<!--
Thank you so much for contributing to open source and the Normalizr project!
-->
# Feauture request

Add #354 

# Solution

Added a new param outerSchema, who is propagated recursively between the normalizer functions until the addEntity, who use it to figure the implicit relations between parent and input and (if there are any), add a to a collection or simple property corresponding to the parent id. 

# TODO

- [ ] Add & update tests
- [ ] Ensure CI is passing (lint, tests, flow)
- [ ] Update relevant documentation

17.title: Map the implicit many to one and the one to many relations
17.body:
<!--
When trying to solve more solutions with Normalizr, please keep in mind some of the following goals of the package:
* Be lightweight: small package size (single-digit KiBs, gzipped)
* Be easy: too many options in an API can become confusing
* Be clear: the intended purpose of every method should be as obvious as possible
* Is it easy to do this in "userland"? Would it be better off done there?
-->

# Suggestion

Map the implicit many to one and the one to many relations. For example, with the following models:

```
const user = new schema.Entity('users');
const comment = new schema.Entity('comments');

user.define({ comments: [comment] });
comment.define({ user: user });
```

and an input data as:

```
const input =[
   {
      id:'comment-1',
      user:{
         id:'user-1'
      }
   },
   {
      id:'comment-2',
      user:{
         id:'user-2'
      }
   },
   {
      id:'comment-3',
      user:{
         id:'user-1'
      }
   }
]
```
the output should be:

```
{
   "entities":{
      "users":{
         "user-1":{
            "id":"user-1",
            "comments":[
               "comment-1",
               "comment-3"
            ]
         },
         "user-2":{
            "id":"user-2",
            "comments":[
               "comment-2"
            ]
         }
      },
      "comments":{
         "comment-1":{
            "id":"comment-1",
            "user":"user-1"
         },
         "comment-2":{
            "id":"comment-2",
            "user":"user-2"
         },
         "comment-3":{
            "id":"comment-3",
            "user":"user-1"
         }
      }
   },
   "result":[
      "comment-1",
      "comment-2",
      "comment-3"
   ]
}
```
# Solution

Add to the addentity function the outerschema to figure out the relations between parent and input.

18.title: Null/Undefined valued nested properties of EntitySchemas are always omitted from normalized output

19.title: Better Typescript integration?
19.body: Would it be possible to improve the type declarations so that normalizr maintains the types of the normalized entities, rather than setting them  as `any`.

20.title: Feature request: flowtype the library
